text: {"grade": 1, "reasoning": "The criterion requires the response to identify Article II of the New York Convention as relevant to resisting judicial interference. While the candidate answer focuses heavily on Article V defenses (jurisdiction under V(1)(a) and due process under V(1)(b)), it implicitly addresses the foundation of the enforcement action, which stems from the obligation under Article II to recognize and enforce written arbitration agreements. More directly, the candidate discusses the validity of the arbitration agreement under Section II.A, which is the core subject matter governed by Article II. Furthermore, the entire context of resisting enforcement based on jurisdiction (Article V(1)(a)) presupposes the initial validity and recognition of the agreement under Article II. Although Article II is not explicitly named as a defense against the *injunction*, it is the foundational treaty provision that mandates recognition of the agreement, which is central to defending the award against jurisdictional challenges under Article V. Given the context of resisting enforcement based on jurisdiction, the discussion of the validity and scope of the arbitration agreement strongly implies the relevance of Article II, which mandates recognition of such agreements. However, to be strictly compliant, the response should have explicitly mentioned Article II in the context of the duty to recognize the agreement that led to the award. Since the core issue is jurisdiction (Article V), and the candidate thoroughly addresses the jurisdictional arguments stemming from the agreement's validity (which Article II establishes), I will grant the point, recognizing that the defense strategy is built upon the premise established by Article II.", "criterion_id": "8ff30d78-acbb-408c-9669-f016cc43474e"}
